articles.headline: W.T.O. Says Aid to Airbus for A380 Was Illegal
articles.snippet: Both American and European Union officials declared victory after a confidential finding, which said Airbus received illegal subsidies, was given to trade agencies.
articles.abstract: Both American and European Union officials declared victory after a confidential finding, which said Airbus received illegal subsidies, was given to trade agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A preliminary report by the World Trade Organization has found that Airbus received illegal subsidies for the $13 billion A380 superjumbo jet and several other airplanes, hurting Boeing in the battle for sales, American and European officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: The New Back-to-School Ritual: Quarantines
articles.snippet: As colleges welcome students back, they are keeping those infected with the H1N1 virus at a safe distance.
articles.abstract: As colleges welcome students back, they are keeping those infected with the H1N1 virus at a safe distance.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  It looks like a typical college dormitory: the functional single cots, the students lazing in pajamas and sandals, the laptops and iPhones clicked to Facebook.

articles.headline: Why College Costs Rise, Even in a Recession
articles.snippet: If you have paid college tuition recently, you probably have questions. Where does all that money go? And why doesn’t the price tag ever fall?
articles.abstract: If you have paid college tuition recently, you probably have questions. Where does all that money go? And why doesn’t the price tag ever fall?
articles.lead_paragraph: If you have paid a college tuition bill recently, perhaps the sticker shock has abated and your children have been good enough to friend you on Facebook so you can see what they are doing on your dime.

articles.headline: For Your Health, Froot Loops
articles.snippet: A seal meant to flag healthier food has been granted to the likes of Froot Loops and full-fat mayonnaise, alarming nutritionists.
articles.abstract: A seal meant to flag healthier food has been granted to the likes of Froot Loops and full-fat mayonnaise, alarming nutritionists.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new food-labeling campaign called Smart Choices, backed by most of the nation’s largest food manufacturers, is “designed to help shoppers easily identify smarter food and beverage choices.”

articles.headline: The Cloud Hanging Over Skype
articles.snippet: A lawsuit lurking in the background of the eBay-Skype sale raises some questions.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit lurking in the background of the eBay-Skype sale raises some questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early this week, eBay announced that after four years of owning Skype, the popular, and free, online phone service, it had sold the company to an investor group for around $2 billion. The investors included the Silicon Valley private equity firm Silver Lake Partners; Marc Andreessen’s new venture capital firm, Andreessen Horowitz; a London firm called Index Ventures; and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board. Under the terms of the deal, eBay will retain a 35 percent stake in Skype, giving it a valuation of $2.75 billion.

articles.headline: Teenage Jobless Rate Reaches Record High
articles.snippet: The rate for August was the highest since the government began keeping track in 1948 and nearly three times that of the nonteenage population.
articles.abstract: The rate for August was the highest since the government began keeping track in 1948 and nearly three times that of the nonteenage population.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pity the unemployed, but pity especially the young and unemployed.

articles.headline: States Cut Back and Layoffs Hit Even Recipients of Stimulus Aid
articles.snippet: A Minnesota bus factory that became a symbol of the stimulus when Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited has had to lay off workers after cutbacks in Illinois delayed orders.
articles.abstract: A Minnesota bus factory that became a symbol of the stimulus when Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited has had to lay off workers after cutbacks in Illinois delayed orders.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. CLOUD, Minn.  It was just five months ago that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. made the New Flyer bus factory here a symbol of the stimulus. With several cabinet secretaries in tow, he held a town-hall-style meeting at the factory, where he praised the company as “an example of the future” and said that it stood to get more orders for its hybrid electric buses thanks to the $8.4 billion that the stimulus law devotes to mass transit.

articles.headline: Drought Puts Focus on a Side of India Left Out of Progress
articles.snippet: The crisis has underscored the problems facing Indian agriculture as the population expands at the same time that water resources come under greater pressure.
articles.abstract: The crisis has underscored the problems facing Indian agriculture as the population expands at the same time that water resources come under greater pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: PIPRI VILLAGE, India  Two very different recent scenes from India: At a power breakfast in New Delhi for many of the country’s corporate leaders and top economic officials, Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee declared that India had “weathered the storm” of the global economic crisis and was witnessing “green shoots” in industry and services that signaled a return to more rapid growth by next year.

articles.headline: Turning to Tie-Ins, Lego Thinks Beyond the Brick
articles.snippet: Lego has rebuilt itself, but its new Hollywood-themed products are a far cry from the purely imagination-oriented play that drove the company for years.
articles.abstract: Lego has rebuilt itself, but its new Hollywood-themed products are a far cry from the purely imagination-oriented play that drove the company for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Billund, Denmark

articles.headline: Wall Street Pursues Profit in Bundles of Life Insurance
articles.snippet: Wall Street bankers plan to buy life insurance policies that ill and elderly people sell for cash and package hundreds or thousands of them together into bonds.
articles.abstract: Wall Street bankers plan to buy life insurance policies that ill and elderly people sell for cash and package hundreds or thousands of them together into bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the mortgage business imploded last year, Wall Street investment banks began searching for another big idea to make money. They think they may have found one.

articles.headline: A Dream Interrupted at Boeing
articles.snippet: Boeing says it is getting back on track on the 787 Dreamliner, which is two years late. The company says it outsourced too much.
articles.abstract: Boeing says it is getting back on track on the 787 Dreamliner, which is two years late. The company says it outsourced too much.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERETT, Wash.

articles.headline: They Left Fannie Mae, but We Got the Legal Bills
articles.snippet: As a result of the Fannie takeover, taxpayers are paying millions in legal defense bills for three top former executives.
articles.abstract: As a result of the Fannie takeover, taxpayers are paying millions in legal defense bills for three top former executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRECISELY one year ago, we lucky taxpayers took over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giants that contributed mightily to the wild and crazy home-loan-boom-turned-bust. In that rescue operation, the Treasury agreed to pony up as much as $200 billion to keep Fannie in the black, coughing up cash whenever its liabilities exceed its assets. According to the company’s most recent quarterly financial statement, the Treasury will, by Sept. 30, have handed over $45 billion to shore up the company’s net worth.

articles.headline: China Oil Deal Is New Source of Strife Among Iraqis
articles.snippet: The presence of a foreign company with vast resources drilling oil in a poor, rural corner of Iraq has awakened a wave of discontent in the area.
articles.abstract: The presence of a foreign company with vast resources drilling oil in a poor, rural corner of Iraq has awakened a wave of discontent in the area.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASIT PROVINCE, Iraq  When China’s biggest oil company signed the first post-invasion oil field development contract in Iraq last year, the deal was seen as a test of Iraq’s willingness to open an industry that had previously prohibited foreign investment.

articles.headline: Teams Seeking Remains Dig Back to World War II
articles.snippet: The U.S. military has paid new attention to accounting for a majority of the Americans missing from the war.
articles.abstract: The U.S. military has paid new attention to accounting for a majority of the Americans missing from the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAULER, Germany  At the start of the Battle of the Bulge in December 1944, an American bomber was shot down by German fighter planes and sent into a fiery, nose-first crash in a cow pasture here. The pilot’s body was never found.

articles.headline: White House Official Resigns After G.O.P. Criticism
articles.snippet: A relatively minor figure in the administration, Van Jones had threatened to become a significant distraction.
articles.abstract: A relatively minor figure in the administration, Van Jones had threatened to become a significant distraction.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  White House officials on Sunday tersely accepted the resignation of the administration’s special adviser for environmental jobs after a number of his past statements became fodder for conservative critics and Republican officials.

articles.headline: Natural Gas Hits a Roadblock in New Energy Bill
articles.snippet: Lawmakers from coal-producing states appear committed to keeping coal as the nation’s primary producer of power.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers from coal-producing states appear committed to keeping coal as the nation’s primary producer of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  The natural gas industry has enjoyed something of a winning streak in recent years. It found gigantic new reserves, low prices are encouraging utilities to substitute gas for coal, and cities are switching to buses fueled by natural gas.

articles.headline: Movie Studios See a Threat in Growth of Redbox
articles.snippet: The Illinois company, which charges $1 a day for DVD rentals, expects to have 22,000 machines in supermarkets, Wal-Mart stores and fast-food outlets by December.
articles.abstract: The Illinois company, which charges $1 a day for DVD rentals, expects to have 22,000 machines in supermarkets, Wal-Mart stores and fast-food outlets by December.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  In 1982, just as the VHS tape was taking off, a “Star Wars” buff named Mitch Lowe had a radical idea. What about building a vending machine that could rent movies? He called his invention Video Droid.

articles.headline: Like Apple, TV Explores Must-Have Applications
articles.snippet: DirecTV and Verizon have app stores. Other cable, satellite and phone companies are working on new technology, but the industry is still wrestling with many questions.
articles.abstract: DirecTV and Verizon have app stores. Other cable, satellite and phone companies are working on new technology, but the industry is still wrestling with many questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cable and satellite TV business has a big case of iPhone envy.

articles.headline: Panels of Light Fascinate Designers
articles.snippet: A cousin of the still-evolving LED bulb is the organic light-emitting diode, which can give light from a sheet 0.07 inches thick.
articles.abstract: A cousin of the still-evolving LED bulb is the organic light-emitting diode, which can give light from a sheet 0.07 inches thick.
articles.lead_paragraph: LED light bulbs, with their minuscule energy consumption and 20-year life expectancy, have grabbed the consumer’s imagination.

articles.headline: A Struggle Taming Any Debate
articles.snippet: The consumer Web and many traditional media outlets seem to amplify every debate into a frantic broadcast scrum.
articles.abstract: The consumer Web and many traditional media outlets seem to amplify every debate into a frantic broadcast scrum.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the good old days, a president would make a speech and then the opposition would set to feasting on its shortcomings. But that familiar call-and-response has been replaced by the pre-emptive strike.

articles.headline: Fake Afghan Poll Sites Favored Karzai, Officials Assert
articles.snippet: Election workers loyal to President Hamid Karzai set up hundreds of fictitious polling sites that delivered votes for the incumbent, according to officials.
articles.abstract: Election workers loyal to President Hamid Karzai set up hundreds of fictitious polling sites that delivered votes for the incumbent, according to officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghans loyal to President Hamid Karzai set up hundreds of fictitious polling sites where no one voted but where hundreds of thousands of ballots were still recorded toward the president’s re-election, according to senior Western and Afghan officials here.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: Gadget Makers Can Find Thief, but Don’t Ask
articles.snippet: Requests to help locate missing or stolen electronic devices or even to shut down service are typically refused.
articles.abstract: Requests to help locate missing or stolen electronic devices or even to shut down service are typically refused.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, when an item was lost or stolen, a consumer went through three stages of grief: anger, mourning and acceptance. You would be miffed, then sad and then you would move on, in large part because moving on was the only option.

articles.headline: Out of Work, and Too Down to Search On
articles.snippet: Millions of hidden casualties of the Great Recession are not counted in the unemployment rate because they have stopped looking for work.
articles.abstract: Millions of hidden casualties of the Great Recession are not counted in the unemployment rate because they have stopped looking for work.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were left out of the latest unemployment rate, as they are every month: millions of hidden casualties of the Great Recession who are not counted in the rate because they have stopped looking for work.

articles.headline: Rebuff by Cadbury Doesn’t Deter Kraft
articles.snippet: Kraft Foods said it would pursue the $16.7 billion takeover even after its offer was rejected for being too low.
articles.abstract: Kraft Foods said it would pursue the $16.7 billion takeover even after its offer was rejected for being too low.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Determined to become a global food and confectionery giant, Kraft Foods said Monday that it would pursue a $16.7 billion takeover of Cadbury, the British chocolate maker, even after Cadbury rejected that offer as too low.
